There are two roles that grant access to content explorer and it is granted using the Microsoft Purview compliance portal:

Content Explorer List viewer: Membership in this role group allows you to see each item and its location in list view. The data classification list viewer role has been pre-assigned to this role group.

Content Explorer Content viewer: Membership in this role group allows you to view the contents of each item in the list. The data classification content viewer role has been pre-assigned to this role group.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/data-classification-content-explorer

discussion.content:
N, N, Y

Admin1 does not have access to Content Explorer as they have not been assigned an appropriate admin role to access the tab.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/data-classification-content-explorer

In order to get access to the content explorer tab, an account must be assigned membership in any one of these roles or role groups.

Microsoft 365 role groups

Global administrator
Compliance administrator
Security administrator
Compliance data administrator

comments.content:
You don’t need the Microsoft Entra ID roles (like Global Administrator, Compliance Administrator, Security Administrator, or Compliance Data Administrator) to use the following roles:

Content Explorer List Viewer

Content Explorer Content Viewer

Why?
The permissions for Content Explorer are independent of Microsoft Entra ID roles. This means that even if a user is not a Global Administrator or Security Administrator, they can still be granted access to Content Explorer by assigning them one of the following roles:

Content Explorer List Viewer: View item names and metadata.

Content Explorer Content Viewer: View the actual contents of files and emails.

discussion.content:
Correct! ChatGPT: 
Analysis: Admin1 has the Content Explorer Content Viewer role, which explicitly allows viewing the actual contents of items.
Answer: Yes ✅
2. Admin2 can view the contents of File1 by using Content Explorer.
Analysis: Admin2 has the Content Explorer List Viewer role, which allows viewing item names and metadata but not the actual contents. This is confirmed by the permissions table.
Answer: No ❌
3. Admin2 can use Content Explorer to verify that Label2 is assigned to Mail1.
Analysis: Admin2 has Content Explorer List Viewer and Security Administrator roles. The List Viewer role lets Admin2 view metadata, including the label information (like Label2). This capability is sufficient to check if Label2 is assigned to Mail1.
Answer: Yes ✅

NO: Admin1 has the Content Explorer List Viewer and Content Explorer Content Viewer roles, which would normally allow viewing content. However, viewing content also requires explicit access to the Content Explorer tab, which Admin1 does not have through roles like Global Administrator, Compliance Administrator, Security Administrator, or Compliance Data Administrator.
NO: Admin2 has the Security Administrator role, which grants access to the Content Explorer tab, and the Content Explorer List Viewer role but lacks the Content Explorer Content Viewer role necessary to view content.
YES: Admin2 can access the Content Explorer due to being a Security Administrator. With the Content Explorer List Viewer role, Admin2 can view the labels assigned to items, even though they can’t view the content of the items themselves.

NNY
Only these 4 roles can see the Content Explorer tab: Global administrator
Compliance administrator
Security administrator
Compliance data administrator
The other 2 roles, Content Viewer and List Viewer, don't let you access Content Explorer tab on their own. They must be added on top of the above 4 roles before you can use them with the content.

Content Explorer Content Viewer View the contents files in Content Explorer.
Content Explorer List Viewer View all items in Content Explorer in list format only.

from MS:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/data-classification-content-explorer
"Membership in these role groups does not allow you to view the list of items in content explorer or to view the contents of the items in content explorer.

There are two roles that grant access to content explorer and it is granted using the Microsoft Purview compliance portal:

Content Explorer List viewer: Membership in this role group allows you to see each item and its location in list view. The data classification list viewer role has been pre-assigned to this role group.

Content Explorer Content viewer: Membership in this role group allows you to view the contents of each item in the list. The data classification content viewer role has been pre-assigned to this role group."

comments.content:
User1@contoso.com:
File1.xlsx: Matches Rule2 (priority 1).
File2.doc: Matches Rule2 (priority 1).
File3.pptx: Matches Rule1 (priority 0).
File4.txt: Matches Rule1 (priority 0).
Total Notifications: 4
User2@contoso.com:
File2.doc: Matches Rule3 (priority 2), but Rule2 takes precedence, so no notification.
File3.pptx: Matches Rule3 (priority 2), but Rule1 takes precedence, so no notification.
File4.txt: Matches Rule3 (priority 2), but Rule1 takes precedence, so no notification.
Total Notifications: 0
4 file so 4 notification

Policy priority order: When an item matches multiple policies and those policies have identical actions, the actions from the highest priority policy is applied.

My doubt is about if files .doc and .txt are included. If they are:

File1.xlsx: Matches Rule 2 (Priority 1) for user1@contoso.com.
File2.doc: Matches Rule 2 (Priority 1) for user1@contoso.com and Rule 3 (Priority 2) for user2@contoso.com. Since Rule 2 has a higher priority, it applies to user1@contoso.com.
File3.pptx: Matches Rule 1 (Priority 0) for user1@contoso.com.
File4.txt: Matches Rule 1 (Priority 0) for user1@contoso.com.

User1@contoso.com will receive notifications for File1.xlsx, File2.doc, File3.pptx, and File4.txt.
User2@contoso.com will not receive any notifications because Rule 2 has a higher priority than Rule 3 for File2.doc, and the rest of the files are matched by rules with higher priorities.

discussion.content:
The explanation is:
When content is evaluated against rules, the rules are processed in priority order. If content matches multiple rules, the first rule evaluated that has the most restrictive action is enforced. For example, if content matches all of the following rules, Rule 3 is enforced because it's the highest priority, most restrictive rule:

 Rule 1: only notifies users
 Rule 2: notifies users, restricts access, and allows user overrides
 Rule 3: notifies users, restricts access, and doesn't allow user overrides
 Rule 4: restricts access

Rules 1, 2, and 4 would be evaluated, but not applied. In this example, matches for all of the rules are recorded in the audit logs and shown in the DLP reports, even though only the most restrictive rule is applied.

So because the most restrictive rule, I think :
User1--> 4
User2--> 3

See prioritet
User1 only get 1 notifiering
User 2 get 1 notifiering
becuase of flood notifiering and priority user1 only get one mail

Answer
User1 : 4
User2 : 0

Here higher priority applies and it prevents other rules with lower priority.

File1.xlsx is copied 
Only Rule2 is triggered 
No priority applied 
User1 Receives a notification

File2.doc is copied 
Rule2 and Rule3 are triggered 
Rule2 has priority 
User1 Receives a notification

File3.pptx is copied 
Rule1, Rule2 and Rule3 are triggered 
Rule1 has priority 
User1 Receives a notification

File4.txt is copied 
Rule1, Rule2 and Rule3 are triggered 
Rule1 has priority 
User1 Receives a notification

.txt is supported : https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/endpoint-dlp-learn-about

1 notification for user2

here is the scenario

Rule1 high priority is not matching on File1 for user1 (no alert)
Rule2 second priority is matching on File2 for user1 (alert)
Rule1 high priority is matching on File2 for use1 (alert) file3 and file4 is not processed since high priority rule is already matched
2 alert for user2

Rule3 is for user2
3 or more is matching for file2 = priority2
priority 2 is already matched for file2, hence no more notification applicable

To prevent a flood of notification emails, all matches that occur within a one-minute time window that are for the same DLP rule and on the same location are grouped together in the same alert.
Each rule launch a notification. For this reason user1 receive 2 notifications (Rule1 and Rule2) and user2 1 notification (Rule 3).

Answer is 2, 1

Define specific actions (e.g., sharing files or folders).

Notify designated recipients (e.g., the HR manager).

DLP Policies: These can be configured to monitor actions within a specific SharePoint site, such as the HR SharePoint site and notify specific individuals, such as the HR manager, when a sharing event occurs that matches the policy criteria.

Defender Alert Policies: Notifications are typically sent to security teams or administrators and focus on system-wide or security-related incidents such as phishing, malware, and suspicious activities and are sent to security teams or administrators

User (member or guest) shared a file, folder, or site in SharePoint or OneDrive for Business with a user in your organization's directory. The value in the Detailcolumn for this activity identifies the name of the user the resource was shared with and whether this user is a member or a guest. This activity is often accompanied by a second event that describes how the user was granted access to the resource; for example, adding the user to a group that has access to the resource.

If I only want a notification, but no alert: DLP

questions.question_text:
You need to notify the manager of the human resources department when a user in the department shares a file or folder from the department's Microsoft SharePoint site.

What should you do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Correct Answer
https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/microsoft/view/68006-exam-ms-101-topic-2-question-32-discussion/

To block users from downloading a file named File1.exe in Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, you should use an **indicator** (B). An indicator in Microsoft Defender for Endpoint is a security tool that allows you to block or allow files, URLs, domains, and IP addresses. Here's how you can do it:

1. Sign in to the Microsoft 365 Defender portal.
2. Under Endpoints, go to Settings.
3. Under the Rules heading, you will find the Indicators option.
4. Here, you can add the file (File1.exe) that you want to block.

Please note that a suppression rule (A) is used to stop alerts from being triggered by known safe files and behaviors. A device configuration profile (C) is used to manage settings and features on devices in your organization.

B. an indicator
In Microsoft Defender for Endpoint, indicators can be used to specify files, URLs, or IP addresses that should be allowed or blocked across your organization. By creating a file indicator for File1.exe and setting it to "block," you can prevent users from downloading this specific file.

Documentation here confirms the answer most people have given:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/defender-endpoint/advanced-features?view=o365-worldwide

To turn Allow or block files on:

In the navigation pane, select Settings > Endpoints > General > Advanced features > Allow or block file.

Toggle the setting between On and Off.

Select Save preferences at the bottom of the page.

After turning on this feature, you can block files via the ****Add Indicator**** tab on a file's profile page.

Selected Answer: C
C. a device configuration profile.

A device configuration profile is used to configure settings on devices that are enrolled in Microsoft Defender for Endpoint. You can use a device configuration profile to block users from downloading a file by adding the file to the Block list.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. the Microsoft Entra admin center.

The Microsoft Entra admin center is the new unified portal for managing Azure AD and Microsoft 365 identities. It provides a single pane of glass for managing users, groups, roles, and permissions.

To compare the permissions of each role in Azure AD, you can use the Role assignments blade in the Microsoft Entra admin center. This blade shows all of the roles that are assigned to each user, and you can easily compare the permissions of each role.
